UNIT 1    Prepare for Ratios, Rates, and Circles    Proportional Relationships: Ratios, Rates, and Circles
©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.

Self Check
Before starting this unit, check off the skills you know below.
As you complete each lesson, see how many more skills you can check off!
Find actual distance given a scale drawing.
Find actual area given a scale drawing.
Draw a scale drawing at a different scale.
Find unit rates with complex fractions.
Identify proportional relationships and the constant of proportionality.
Write an equation to represent a proportional relationship.
Find the circumference and area of circles.

Make connections between representations of proportional relationships by
explaining how they are similar and different.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
UNIT 1  STEM Stories
1ST

Noramay Cadena
Noramay Cadena is an engineer and entrepreneur from
California. She earned degrees in mechanical engineering and
worked in the aerospace industry before turning her focus to
business. Now, she supports underrepresented individuals
and companies in technology and engineering fields.

Noramay Cadena was born in Mexico and grew up in
Los Angeles, California. Her family had little money.
Sometimes they did not have running water or electricity.
They also lived in a very supportive community. As a
teenager, Noramay worked to help support her family.

Noramay worked hard in
school. She excelled in a special
science, technology, and math
program in high school.

During her junior year, a
recruiter encouraged
students to apply to the
Massachusetts Institute of
Technology (MIT). His words
inspired Noramay to apply.
When she was accepted,
the newspaper ran a story
about her accomplishment.
Noramay’s parents and
members of her community
showered her with support.
Even people she didn’t know
sent her supportive letters
and money to help her.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
UNIT 1  STEM Stories
2ST

Noramay identifies problems and perseveres in solving them. As an engineer, she worked
hard to solve problems related to building satellites and airplanes. She also perseveres to
support others in overcoming barriers to working in STEM fields.

1 	 Think about how Noramay received and gave support. When
have others supported you? How do you support others?

2 	 Think about how Noramay perseveres to solve problems. What
is a problem you worked hard to solve?

At MIT, Noramay found support. After earning
a degree in mechanical engineering, she worked
as an engineer on satellites and airplanes.

Now, Noramay supports other people. She helps
them get money to start their businesses, and she
gives them advice about how to be successful.

Noramay went on to earn advanced degrees
in engineering and business. She also
started Latinas in STEM, an organization
that supports Latinas in STEM careers.

the ratio of the number of Gs to the number of Hs, G : H, for each group below.
Write the letter of the group in the correct column of the table.

a.	 G G G G H H H
e.	 G G G H H H H
i.	 G G G G G H H
b.	 G H G H G H G
f.	 H H G G H H G

h.	 H G H G H G H
l.	 H H G H H G H
Ratios of Gs to Hs (G : H)

Find the ratio of Gs to Hs for the group below. Which column in the table above does
this ratio belong to?
G  H  G  H  G  H  G  H  G  G  H  G  H  G  H  G  G  G  G  H  H

Write your own GH group that has one of the ratios in the table. Then meet with a
partner to discuss which column each ratio belongs to.

LESSON 1  Solve Problems Involving Scale

This week your student is learning about scale drawings. In a scale drawing,
the size of an original figure changes, but its shape does not change.
Here are some examples of scale drawings that you may be familiar with.
•  A floor plan is a scale drawing of the actual layout of space in a building.
•  A state road map is a scale drawing of the actual roads in the state.

Scale drawings are typically used when objects are either too small or too large to
be shown at their actual sizes. Floor plans and maps are drawn smaller than actual
size. Suppose a floor plan is drawn so that 1 inch on the floor plan represents an
actual distance of 3 feet. For that floor plan, the scale is 1 in. to 3 ft.
Your student will be solving scale drawing problems like the one below.

The scale from an actual volcano to a drawing of the volcano is 50 m to
5 cm. The height of the drawing of the volcano is 25 cm. How tall is the
actual volcano?
➤ONE WAY to find the height is to use a double number line.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to use a scale factor.
The scale from the drawing to the actual volcano is 5 cm for every 50 m, so the

scale factor from the drawing to the volcano is ​ 50
··
5 ​ , or 10.
Multiply the height of the model by the scale factor: 25 3 10 5 250.
Using either method, the height of the actual volcano is 250 m.

Use the next page to start a
conversation about scale.

LESSON 1  Solve Problems Involving Scale
©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
LESSON 1  Solve Problems Involving Scale
4

Activity Thinking About Scale
Around You

➤Do this activity together to investigate scale in the
real world.

Have you ever taken a long road trip and come across
some large roadside attractions?

The world’s largest cowboy boots are a sculpture in
Texas. They are over 35 feet tall! A cowboy boot is
normally just 12 inches, or 1 foot, tall.

Gift shops often have models of buildings that fit in the
palm of your hand. In Washington, D.C., you can get a
Lincoln Memorial model that is 6.5 inches tall. The actual memorial is 80 feet tall!
These giant and tiny models are scale copies of real-life objects.

Where do you see scale drawings and
scale copies in the world around you?

LESSON 1  Solve Problems Involving Scale
Look Back Which of the triangles could be the same shape as nA? Explain.

Look Ahead nD is a scale drawing, or a scale copy, of nA. A scale drawing of
a figure is larger or smaller than the original figure but is identical in shape. The
scale is the ratio between the side lengths of the original figure and the
corresponding side lengths of the scale drawing. To make a scale drawing, you can
multiply each length in the original figure by a scale factor to get the
corresponding length in the scale drawing. You can think of the scale factor as a
unit rate.
a.	 Explain why the scale from nLMN to nPQR could be 1 : 3.
b.	 Explain why the scale factor from nLMN to nPQR is 3.
c.	 What is the value of x? Describe two different ways you can find it.

Reflect Yukio says the scale from nPQR to nLMN is 3 : 1. Is Yukio correct?
Explain.

You can use a scale factor to find the dimensions.

from the drawing to the bedroom is ​ 10
··
1 ​ , or 10.

A blueprint for the floor of a natural history museum is shown.
The scale of the museum to the blueprint is 20 yd to 1 in. What
is the area of the floor of the actual Great Hall?
You can use a table of equivalent ratios to find the actual dimensions.
The actual floor is 35 yd long and 15 yd wide.
You can use a scale factor to find the area of the actual floor.
The scale from the blueprint to the museum is 20 : 1. So, the scale factor is 20.

LESSON 3  Understand Proportional Relationships
47
This week your student is exploring proportional relationships.

Here are some examples of proportional relationships that you may be
familiar with.

•  Ingredients of a recipe are proportional to one another: you use the same
proportions when making smaller or larger batches.

•  The earnings of hourly employees are proportional to the number of hours
worked: a person who works 3 hours will earn 3 times the hourly wage.

Suppose Ichiro’s hourly wage is $15. When he works 4 hours, he earns $60.
His hourly wage of $15 does not change. In Ichiro’s case, the constant of
proportionality that relates amount earned to hours worked is 15. When a
relationship is proportional, constant of proportionality is another term for unit rate.
Your student will be modeling proportional relationships like the one below.

Jennifer goes apple picking with her family at a nearby farm. Each pound
of apples they pick costs $2. The total cost depends on the number of
pounds of apples they pick.
➤ONE WAY to represent a proportional relationship is with a table.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to use a double number line.

Both representations show that the cost is always twice the number of pounds of
apples. That means the constant of proportionality in this situation is 2.

Use the next page to start a conversation
about proportional relationships.

LESSON 4  Represent Proportional Relationships

This week your student is learning about
graphs and equations that can represent
proportional relationships.

One way to represent a proportional
relationship is with a graph. The graph will
be a straight line that goes through the
origin, or the point (0, 0).

Another way is with an equation that tells
you how many y you have for every one x.
The equation for the proportional
relationship at the right is y = 8x.
Your student will solve problems like the one below.

The table compares the number of people who ride a rollercoaster to the
number of rollercoaster cars they fill. Is this a proportional relationship?

➤ONE WAY to recognize a proportional relationship is
with a graph.

Plot the pairs of values as ordered pairs and connect the
points. The graph is a straight line that passes through
(0, 0), so the relationship is proportional.

➤ANOTHER WAY to recognize a proportional relationship
is to check if the ratios are equivalent.

The ratios 3 : 18, 5 : 30, 6 : 36, and 8 : 48 are all equivalent.
In each case, you can multiply the first quantity by 6 to
get the second quantity.

Both ways show that the relationship
is proportional.

LESSON 6  Solve Area and Circumference Problems Involving Circles
Solve Area and Circumference Problems Involving Circles
This week your student is learning about the circumference and area of circles.

Circumference is the distance around a circle,
or its perimeter. Area is the amount of space
inside a circle.

The radius, r, is the distance from the center of a
circle to any point on the circle. The diameter, d, is
the distance from one side of the circle to the
other, passing through the center of the circle.
A special relationship exists between the
circumference of a circle and its diameter.

No matter the size of the circle, the quotient ​ circumference
···········
diameter
​ is constant. This quotient
is called pi, and the symbol for pi is p. The exact value of p is a decimal that goes
on forever without repeating. You can approximate p with a decimal or a fraction.
The formulas for the circumference and area of a circle involve p.

Circumference: C 5 pd
Area: A 5 pr2
Your student will be solving circumference and area problems like the one below.

A circular traffic sign has diameter 36 inches. How can you measure
the traffic sign?

Use the next page to start a conversation
about circumference and area of circles.

➤ONE WAY to measure the traffic sign
is to find its circumference.

➤ANOTHER WAY to measure the traffic
sign is to find its area.

The diameter is 36 in. So, the radius
is 18 in.

LESSON 6  Solve Area and Circumference Problems Involving Circles
©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.

98

LESSON 6 | SOLVE AREA AND CIRCUMFERENCE PROBLEMS INVOLVING CIRCLES

Activity Thinking About Circles
Around You
➤Do this activity together to investigate circles in the real world.

Have you ever wondered why runners start at different spots
on a track instead of lining up together? This is called a
staggered start.

Since tracks have semicircles (or half circles) on the ends, if all
the runners lined up together, runners in outer lanes would
need to run farther than runners in inner lanes. Why? Because
the circumference of the outer lane is greater than the
circumference of the inner lane.

Staggering starting positions ensures that all runners run the
same distance!

UNIT 2  STEM Stories

Larry Kwak
Larry Kwak is a physician and scientist. He has made
breakthroughs in treating cancers of the blood with vaccines
that are personalized for each patient. As a doctor and
researcher, Larry is dedicated to helping patients, inventing
new treatments, and making medical discoveries.

Larry was born in 1959 and grew up in
Lawrence, Kansas. His parents had
moved to the United States from Korea
to continue their education.

In high school, Larry had an internship at a
hospital. His advisor invited Larry to look at human
cells under a microscope and imagine how healthy
cells could be used to fight cancer cells.

Larry’s parents encouraged him to choose a career that would help
people. Larry wanted to fight cancer. He studied medicine and became
a medical doctor. He also earned a Ph.D. as a research scientist.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
UNIT 2  STEM Stories

Larry looks for and uses regularity in repeated reasoning. That means he does multiple
experiments and looks for consistent results. He uses those results to help his patients.

1 	 Larry is inventive in treating cancer. When have you found a
new way to do something? How did that help you or others?

2 	 Larry uses repeated reasoning during experiments. When do
you reason? How does reasoning help you learn?

Larry has received several awards for
his influential work with cancer vaccines
and for his contributions to medicine.

Larry uses a
patient’s cancer
cells to make a
vaccine specific
to them. Larry
and others in his
lab developed
a lymphoma
vaccine that is
one of the first
examples of
personalized
medicine.

Larry enjoys seeing breakthroughs that give
patients hope. He says he wakes up every day
looking forward to a new discovery.

Most doctors conduct research or practice medicine. Larry
does both. He works in a field called translational research. In
this field, a doctor develops treatments and then uses them to
treat patients in a medical practice. In translational research,
patients receive new treatments sooner.

LESSON 7  Understand Addition with Negative Integers

Use the next page to start a conversation
about addition with negative integers.

This week your student is exploring addition with integers. The set of integers
includes all whole numbers and their opposites. They can be positive, negative,
or zero.
Here are some examples of situations in which you might need to add integers:
•  It is 28°F and the temperature increases by 15°F. What is the new temperature?

•  A hiking trail starts at 150 feet below sea level and increases by 600 feet in
elevation. What is the ending elevation?

You can add integers just like you can add whole numbers. If you add an integer
to its opposite, the sum is 0. The integers 24 and 4 are opposites.
Opposites, like 4 and 24, form zero pairs because their sum is 0.
Your student will be modeling addition problems like the one below.
➤ONE WAY to model addition with negative integers is with integer chips.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to use a number line. Move left to add a negative number.

136

What are other times that you combine positive

LESSON 7 | UNDERSTAND ADDITION WITH NEGATIVE INTEGERS

Activity Thinking About
Positive and Negative Numbers
Around You

➤Do this activity together to investigate positive and
negative numbers in the real world.

Have you ever played a team sport and wondered how
you impacted the game? Basketball has a statistic used
to measure this called plus-minus.

To find a player’s plus-minus, find how many points
that player’s team scored while the player was in the
game. Then find how many points the other team
scored during that same time, and write that as a
negative number. Then add the two numbers.

So, if your team scores 10 points while you are in the
game and the other team scores fewer than 10, your plus-minus is positive.
But if the other team scores more than 10 points, your plus-minus is negative.

LESSON 9  Understand Subtraction with Negative Integers
This week your student is exploring subtraction with negative integers.

Your student has already seen that subtracting a number and adding the opposite
of that number have the same result.

Now your student will see how to use this fact to subtract negative integers.
The opposite of a negative integer is a positive integer. So, subtracting a negative
number and adding the opposite positive number have the same result.
Your student will be modeling subtraction problems with negative integers.
➤ONE WAY to model subtraction with negative integers is with integer chips.

➤ANOTHER WAY is to use a number line. To show adding a negative number on a
number line, draw an arrow to the left. To show subtracting a negative number on
a number line, draw an arrow to the right.

UNIT 3  STEM Stories

Frieda Zames
Frieda Zames (1932–2005) was a mathematics professor and
dedicated advocate for people with disabilities. She taught
mathematics for students of all ages and was a powerful
leader in the disability rights movement. She also made her
college campus more accessible for people with disabilities.

Frieda Zames was born in Brooklyn, New York. As a
child, she became ill with polio. Frieda spent a lot of
time in the hospital and missed school. Polio also
made it necessary for Frieda to use crutches and
then a scooter for the rest of her life.

Frieda made up for lost time in school by
reading and studying hard. She excelled
in math during high school and earned a
scholarship to Brooklyn College.

In 1977, Frieda wrote a paper titled
“Surface Area and the Cylinder Area
Paradox.” For this paper, she won the 1978
George Pólya Award in recognition of
excellent mathematical writing.

After college, Frieda worked during the day and
studied at night to earn a Ph.D. in mathematics
from New York University. She worked as a
mathematics professor for nearly 30 years at
the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT).

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.

access for people with disabilities and critiqued institutions that resisted change.

Frieda taught math
classes for college
students and for ten
years was co-director
of a math and science
program at NJIT for
elementary and middle-
school students with
disabilities. She also
made the college campus
more accessible for
people with disabilities.

In the 1970s, Frieda joined Disabled in Action, an
organization that worked to pass and enforce
laws making public places and transportation
accessible for people with disabilities. Multiple
times, Frieda served as vice-president and
president of the organization.

The 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act
(ADA) made it illegal to discriminate
against people with disabilities. Frieda
went to court to require businesses to
install ramps and wider doorways. Frieda
was a leader who worked with others to
make public places accessible for all.

This week your student is exploring multiplication with negative integers.
Below are some examples of multiplying positive and negative integers that
you may be familiar with.

•  You can pay a bill by having the payment taken out of your bank account each
month. To find the change in your account over several months, you can multiply
the monthly change in value (negative) by the number of months (positive).

•  A submarine’s rate of change in elevation can be measured in feet per second.
When it dives deeper, this rate is negative. You can multiply the rate (negative) by
the amount of time it moves (positive) to find its change in elevation.

LESSON 13  Express Rational Numbers as Terminating or Repeating Decimals
This week your student is learning about expressing fractions as decimals.

Every rational number can be written as a fraction. You can divide the numerator
by the denominator to find the decimal form of a fraction.

A terminating decimal like 0.75 ends. A repeating decimal like 0.66 . . . never
ends. It repeats the same digit or group of digits over and over. Another way to
write a repeating decimal is to put a bar over the digits that repeat. So, 0.66 . . . can
be written as 0.​ ··
6 ​. Your student will be solving problems like the one below.

orange weighs 0.375 lb. Is the orange labeled accurately?

LESSON 14  Use the Four Operations with Negative Numbers

This week your student is learning about using approximations to show that their
answers to problems involving operations with rational numbers are reasonable.

Your student has already learned to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational
numbers. In this lesson, your student will focus on using estimation to approximate
the results of calculations. Finding an approximation can be a useful tool to make
sense of a problem. Approximating an answer first can also help to determine
whether an answer is reasonable.

One way you can make an approximation is by rounding rational numbers to the
nearest integer.
Your student will be solving problems like the one below.

Ms. Seda deposits $41.60 into her bank account on Wednesday.
On Thursday, she pays two bills for $17.15 and $26.85 from the account.
Does Ms. Seda have more or less money in the account after the
withdrawals than she did before the deposit?
➤ONE WAY to find the answer is to approximate.
Round each amount to the nearest $1.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to find the exact answer.

Both the estimate and the exact answer show that Ms. Seda has less money in the
account after the withdrawals than she did before the deposit. Since the exact
answer is close to the approximation, you know the answer is reasonable.
Use the Four Operations with Negative Numbers

Use the next page to start a conversation
about rational numbers.

LESSON 14 | USE THE FOUR OPERATIONS WITH NEGATIVE NUMBERS

Activity Thinking About Rational
Numbers Around You

➤Do this activity together to investigate rational numbers
in the real world.

Most movies cost many millions of dollars to produce. How
do movie studios make a profit? One way is from ticket sales.
A movie studio’s ticket sale profit can be represented by the
following expression:
Ticket Price 3 Number of Tickets Sold 2 Cost to Make Movie

So, if the total money from ticket sales is more than the cost
to make the movie, then the movie studio’s profit is positive.
But if the total money from ticket sales is less than the cost to
make the movie, the movie studio’s profit is negative. Movie studios approximate
their costs and sales to decide whether or not a movie is worth making.

What are other situations where
you use rational numbers?

UNIT 4  STEM Stories

Wanda Díaz-Merced
Wanda Díaz-Merced is an astronomer. While working at the
National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA),
Wanda developed software that transforms data into sounds.
She and other scientists use the sound data to learn about
outer space.

Wanda Díaz-Merced was born in Gurabo, Puerto
Rico. Growing up, she and her sister pretended to
fly spacecraft to other galaxies. These games let
them imagine a world beyond their own.

In middle school, Wanda entered the
science fair and won second place.
That success made her feel a career in
science was possible.

In high school, Wanda worked hard to
transform herself into the scientist she
hoped to become. After graduating, she
attended the University of Puerto Rico. During
this time, she began to lose her vision.

By the time she was in her 20s, Wanda had
lost her vision completely. She was
determined to graduate, even though it
meant she had to repeat some courses.
After six years of studying, Wanda earned
a degree in physics.

LESSON 15  Write Equivalent Expressions Involving Rational Numbers

This week your student is learning how to write equivalent expressions that have
both variables and rational numbers.

Many situations can be represented with mathematical expressions. For example,
suppose a movie ticket costs x dollars, and a bag of popcorn costs y dollars. The
expression x 1 y represents the cost of 1 ticket and 1 bag of popcorn. You can
represent the cost of 2 tickets and 2 bags of popcorn with different expressions.

Three possible expressions are x 1 y 1 x 1 y, 2x 1 2y, and 2(x 1 y). These
expressions are equivalent, or represent the same value.
Your student will be solving problems like the one below.

➤ONE WAY to check if the expressions are equivalent is to write both expressions
without parentheses. Combine like terms in the first expression. Multiply to expand
the second expression.

➤ANOTHER WAY is to write both expressions with parentheses. Combine like terms
in the first expression and then factor 23 from each term.

Both ways show that 24x 2 27 2 15x 1 18 2 21x 1 27
and 23(4x 2 6) are equivalent expressions.

LESSON 17  Understand Multi-Step Equations
This week your student is exploring multi-step equations.

You can use a variable to represent an unknown quantity and write an equation
with the variable to represent a situation. Then you can use reasoning to find the
value of the unknown quantity. You can use a hanger diagram to reason about the
value of an unknown quantity.
Your student will be reasoning about situations like the one below.

For a party, Mr. Díaz buys 3 packs of confetti and a banner. He spends a
total of $8. He knows that the banner costs $5, but does not remember
the cost, c, of each pack of confetti. How can you represent this situation?
How can you reason about the cost of each pack of confetti?
➤ONE WAY is to use a hanger diagram.

The hanger diagram models this situation. The bar at the
top is level, showing that the sides are balanced, or equal.

One way to reason about the cost, c, of each pack of
confetti, is to cross off the same number of 1s from
each side.

Now there are three c’s on the left side and three 1s on the
right side. That means each c is equal to 1.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to use an equation.

One way to reason about the cost, c, of each pack of
confetti is to first think about the value of 3c. This means
thinking about what plus 5 equals 8. Since 3 plus 5 equals
8, that means 3c equals 3.

You can then use the value of 3c to reason about the value
of c. If 3 times c equals 3, then c equals 1.

Using either representation, you can reason that the cost of each pack of
confetti is $1.

Use the next page to start a conversation
about multi-step equations.

using algebraic approaches.

One way to solve word problems is to write and solve an equation that represents
the situation. A bar model may help you make sense of a problem. Then you can
use it to write an equation to represent the situation.

A group of 5 friends go to a concert. Each friend buys a ticket that costs $30. Some of
the friends also buy T-shirts that cost $15 each. In total the friends spend $195. How
many T-shirts, x, did the friends buy?

There are often multiple ways to approach solving an equation. Your student will
be solving problems like the one below.

A family buys 2 adult tickets and 4 child tickets to a high school basketball
game. The family spends a total of $28 on tickets. The adult tickets cost $7
each. What is the cost, x, of each child ticket in dollars?

➤ONE WAY to start finding the value of
x is to subtract 14 from both sides of
the equation.

➤ANOTHER WAY to start is to divide
both sides by 4.
Using either method, x 5 3.5. The cost of each child ticket is $3.50.

LESSON 19  Write and Solve Inequalities

Use the next page to start a
conversation about inequalities.
This week your student is learning about solving problems with inequalities.

An inequality uses symbols to show the relationship between two expressions.
The inequality symbols are greater than (.), greater than or equal to ($),
less than (,), and less than or equal to (#).

You can use inequalities to represent situations in everyday life. Solving an
inequality is similar to solving an equation. But when you multiply or divide both
sides of the inequality by a negative number, you reverse the direction of the
inequality symbol.
Your student will be solving problems like the one below.

The sum of 24 times x and 0.7 is at most 16.7. What are all the possible
values of x?
➤ONE WAY to show the possible values is to write and solve an inequality.
➤ANOTHER WAY is to graph the solutions on a number line.

número es el opuesto de ese número; por

adjacent angles  two non-overlapping

side  a line segment that forms part of a

lado  segmento de recta que forma parte
de una figura bidimensional

simple interest  a percent of an original
amount that is borrowed or invested, paid
at the end of a set period of time.

interés simple  porcentaje de una
cantidad original que se toma prestada o
se invierte, pagado al final de un periodo
de tiempo fijo.

skewed left  when most of the data
points of a distribution are clustered
near the greater values.

asimétrica a la izquierda  cuando la
mayoría de los datos de una distribución
se agrupan cerca de los valores más altos.

skewed right  when most of the data
points of a distribution are clustered
near the lesser values.

asimétrica a la derecha  cuando la
mayoría de los datos de una distribución
se agrupan cerca de los valores más bajos.

solution of an equation  a value that
can be substituted for a variable to make
an equation true.

solución de una ecuación  valor que
puede sustituir a una variable para hacer
que una ecuación sea verdadera.

The value 5 is the
solution of the
equation 19 5 4x 2 1
because 19 5 4(5) 2 1.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL43

solution of an inequality  a value that
can be substituted for a variable to make
an inequality true.

solución de una desigualdad  valor
que puede sustituir a una variable para
hacer que una desigualdad sea verdadera.

All values of x less than 5
(x , 5) are solutions of
the inequality 5x , 25.

square  a quadrilateral with 4 right angles
and 4 sides of equal length.

cuadrado  cuadrilátero que tiene 4
ángulos rectos y 4 lados de la misma
longitud.

statistical question  a question that
can be answered by collecting data that
are expected to vary.

pregunta estadística  pregunta que se
puede responder reuniendo datos que se
espera que varíen.

What is the typical amount of
rain in April?

straight angle  an angle that measures
180°. The sides of a straight angle form a
straight line.

ángulo llano  ángulo que mide 180°. Los
lados de un ángulo llano forman una línea
recta.

supplementary angles  two angles
whose measures sum to 180°.

ángulos suplementarios  dos ángulos
cuyas medidas suman 180°.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL44

surface area  the sum of the areas of all
the faces of a three-dimensional figure.

área total  suma de las áreas de todas las
caras de una figura tridimensional.

symmetric  when a distribution has the
same shape on both sides of a middle point.

simétrico  cuando una distribución tiene
la misma forma en ambos lados de un
punto que está en el medio.

tax  a percent of income or of the cost of
goods or services paid to the government.

impuesto  porcentaje del ingreso o del
costo de bienes o servicios que se paga al
gobierno.

A 7% sales tax on a purchase
of $40 is $2.80

term  a number, a variable, or a product
of numbers, variables, and/or expressions.
A term may include an exponent.

término  número, variable o el producto
de números, variables y/o expresiones. Un
término puede tener un exponente.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL45

terminating decimals  decimals that
end, or end in repeated zeros.

decimal finito  decimal en el que
termina un número, o que termina en
ceros repetidos.

theoretical probability  the probability
of an event occurring based on what is
expected to happen.

probabilidad teórica  probabilidad de
que ocurra un evento según lo que se
espera que suceda.

There are two equally likely
outcomes to flipping a coin:
heads up or tails up.

three-dimensional  solid, or having
length, width, and height. For example, a
cube is three-dimensional.

tridimensional  sólido, o que tiene
longitud, ancho y altura. Por ejemplo, un
cubo es tridimensional.
length

trapezoid (exclusive)  a quadrilateral
with exactly one pair of parallel sides.

trapecio (exclusivo)  cuadrilátero que
tiene exactamente un par de lados
paralelos.

trapezoid (inclusive)  a quadrilateral
with at least one pair of parallel sides.

trapecio (inclusivo)  cuadrilátero que
tiene al menos un par de lados paralelos.

tree diagram  a visual that shows all
possible outcomes of an experiment.

diagrama de árbol  representación
visual que muestra todos los resultados
posibles de un experimento.

There are 8 possible outcomes
from flipping a coin 3 times.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL46

trial  a single performance of an
experiment.

ensayo  ejecución única de un
experimento.

triangle  a polygon with exactly 3 sides
and 3 angles.

triángulo  polígono que tiene
exactamente 3 lados y 3 ángulos.

triangular prism  a prism where the
bases are triangles.

prisma triangular  prisma en el que las
bases son triángulos.

two-dimensional  flat, or having
measurement in two directions, like
length and width. For example, a
rectangle is two-dimensional.

bidimensional  plano, o que tiene
medidas en dos direcciones, como
longitud y ancho. Por ejemplo, un
rectángulo es bidimensional.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL47

unit fraction  a fraction with a
numerator of 1. Other fractions are built
from unit fractions.

fracción unitaria  fracción que tiene un
numerador de 1. Otras fracciones se
construyen a partir de fracciones unitarias.

unit rate  the numerical part of a rate. For
the ratio a : b, the unit rate is the
quotient ​ a
·· b ​ .

tasa por unidad  parte numérica de una
tasa. Para la razón a : b, la tasa por unidad
es el cociente ​ a
·· b ​ .

unknown  the value you need to find to
solve a problem.

incógnita  valor que hay que hallar para
resolver un problema.

upper quartile  the middle number
between the median and the maximum in
an ordered set of numbers. The upper
quartile is also called the 3rd quartile or Q3.

cuartil superior  número del medio entre
la mediana y el máximo en un conjunto
ordenado de números. El cuartil superior
también se llama tercer cuartil, o Q3.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL48

variability  how spread out or close
together values in a data set are.

variabilidad  la dispersión o cercanía de
los valores en un conjunto de datos.

There is high variability in
Gavin’s handstand times.

variable  a letter that represents an
unknown number. In some cases, a variable
may represent more than one number.

variable  letra que representa un número
desconocido. En algunos casos, una variable
puede representar más de un número.

vertex  the point where two rays, lines, or
line segments meet to form an angle.

vértice  punto en el que dos semirrectas,
rectas o segmentos de recta se
encuentran y forman un ángulo.

vertical angles  opposite angles formed
when two lines intersect. Vertical angles
have the same measure.

ángulos opuestos por el vértice
ángulos opuestos que se forman cuando se
intersecan dos rectas. Los ángulos opuestos
por el vértice tienen la misma medida.

volume  the amount of space inside a solid
figure. Volume is measured in cubic units
such as cubic inches.

volumen  cantidad de espacio dentro de
una figura sólida. El volumen se mide en
unidades cúbicas como las pulgadas cúbicas.
volume: 24 units3

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL49

whole numbers  the numbers 0, 1, 2, 3,
4, . . . Whole numbers are nonnegative and
have no fractional part.

números enteros  los números 0, 1, 2, 3,
4, . . . Los números enteros no son
negativos y no tienen partes fraccionarias.

x-axis  the horizontal number line in the
coordinate plane.

eje x  recta numérica horizontal en el
plano de coordenadas.

x-coordinate  the first number in an
ordered pair. It tells the point’s horizontal
distance from the y-axis.

coordenada x  primer número en un par
ordenado. Indica la distancia horizontal
del punto al eje y.

©Curriculum Associates, LLC  Copying is not permitted.
Interactive Glossary/Glosario interactivo
GL50

y-axis  the vertical number line in the
coordinate plane.

eje y  recta numérica vertical en el plano
de coordenadas.

y-coordinate  the second number in an
ordered pair. It tells the point’s vertical
distance from the x-axis.

coordenada y  el segundo número en
un par ordenado. Indica la distancia
vertical del punto al eje x.

zero pair  two numbers whose sum is
zero. Opposite numbers form a zero pair.

par cero  dos números cuya suma es
cero. Los números opuestos forman un par
cero.
